Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Student interest in computing as a discipline and a career has been on the decline for several years. The use of digital media to introduce fundamental computer science concepts shows promise to rejuvenate the interest of millennial students. This project builds on previous success to introduce the creation and sharing of artistic works into Computer Science II. It centers on the activity of converting raw data (text) into useful information (art). This requires students to think at multiple levels of abstraction. The project combines active, problem-based and service learning activities. One example of service learning is that college students volunteer as mentors at a local elementary after-school program. Elementary school students are introduced to simple and engaging computer programs to create art. Curricular materials are designed to be reused and easily adapted by other instructors. The approach draws upon the literature for recruiting and retaining underrepresented groups through its emphases on the creation of artistic works, collaboration, social context and reflection.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this project include resuable course modules use artistic works to motivate and demonstrate freshman-/sophomore-level computer science concepts and programming skills, as well as service-learning activities in which university students utilize their knowledge, skills, and creative works to engage elementary students. Examples of the course modules created as part of this project include those that cover the development of a digital synthesizer and its use to compose a song, as well as the development of a digital karaoke machine that bounces a ball over the lyrics of the song being played. The evaluation results of the project indicate that the new course modules were effective in helping students at The University of Alabama (UA) to gain knowledge of the topics covered by those modules. The largest indicated gains were with regard to programming skills that are critical to developing large and efficient software systems. In addition, evaluation results indicate that students who participated in service-learning activities at local elementary schools appreciated the social impact of their general programming skills. Rapid enrollment growth at UA makes drawing conclusions about the impact of the project on student success rates difficult, but throughout the project period, enrollment in the relevant course at UA by non-majors, as well as their rate of success in the course, increased.
